data.text: Contents
Introduction
To enable FY1 level doctors to proactively acknowledge and treat patients' pain appropriately.
Scope
The document is to aid FY1 level doctors to treat patients in pain who are aged 18 years and over that they may see on the wards in the Trust.
Definitions
Roles and responsibilities
All trainee medical staff are responsible for their own clinical competence, and for remaining current in safe practice in managing pain.
The role of the IPMS and of the trainees' mentors is to ensure access to this information via Trust guidance and available training.
Safety
The safest way to treat pain is to keep it simple as follows:
Assess;
Consider risks/ contraindications to analgesics;
Treat, using balanced analgesia;
Evaluate;
Get help if needed;
Review regularly.
Ground rules
Paracetamol can be an effective opioid sparing analgesic. Prescribe regularly.

Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) carry clinical risk – check for contra-indications and limit duration to 5 days, then review. Consider gastric protection; proton pump inhibitor or H2 receptor blocker.
Choose your opioid and avoid changing without clinical reason. Inadequate analgesia may be dosage related.
Titrate according to the patient's needs and adjust background doses accordingly. PRN oramorph or subcutaneous (SC) morphine is prescribed hourly to allow effective titration.

Using all three of the groups of analgesics is called ‘balanced analgesia', and increases the chances of efficacy by targeting different parts of the pain mechanism at once. Additional use of adjuvants may be helpful depending on the type of pain.
Pre-empt adverse effects - prescribe anti-emetics and naloxone, consider bowel management. Use smaller doses in the elderly and renal impairment.
Analgesic step ladder and balanced analgesia
The analgesic stepladder below is a tool to promote a stepwise, logical approach at the treatment of mild, moderate and severe pain.
Acute Pain Stepladder
SEVERE PAIN (Score 3)
Epidural analgesia or

data.url: 07055 Guidance for trainee doctors - acute pain management 4.0.007.jpeg

data.text: Treatment of severe pain
(Refer to Management of Severe pain/06007)
Opioids
(Morphine IV, PCA, S/C, IM, PO)
8.1.1 The standard drug of choice, morphine is as effective as any opioid. With no ceiling dose, it can be titrated against the pain to effect. Tolerance may occur with repeated use.

8.1.2 The intravenous route is only suitable for high dependency areas (A&E, ITU, HDU, CCU, recovery). Intravenous opioids should be delivered by a trained practitioner and titrated slowly whilst monitoring for adverse effects. 100% bioavailable, the blood-brain barrier is breached within 1 to 2 minutes.

8.1.3 If you consider that a patient may benefit from Patient Controlled Analgesia (PCA) contact the pain team. The opioid is delivered intravenously at 1 to 2 mg doses on demand with a 5 minute lockout. Specific wards only accept patients with a PCA: these wards have had specialist training to enable them to safely look after the patient with this device. A list of wards that accept PCAs is readily available from Recovery or the Pain Service. PCAs do not provide background analgesia.

8.1.4 The subcutaneous (SC) morphine algorithm is an alternative if the patient is unable to take drugs by mouth, and PCA is unsuitable or unavailable. Absorption through the muscle is slower than intravenously but still 100% bioavailable, making the effect last longer. Pre-printed prescription stickers are available:
See appropriate protocols for IM/SC/IV/PO/PCA
Broomfield Hospital prescription Subcutaneous/Intramuscular
MORPHINE via indwelling cannula Bolus: 7.5mg 10mg  * please tick Titration: 1hrly PRN
As per IPMS guidelines

8.1.5 Oral opioids are absorbed through the gut with first pass metabolism removing up to 2/3 active analgesic efficacy. This remains the least invasive route of administration. If converting from IV or SC: once analgesia is achieved, prescribe a maintenance oral regime if tolerated; e.g. regular oramorph, plus prn. Do not prescribe multiple routes: eg ‘morphine 10mg IV/SC/IM'. Doses must be appropriate to the route – if 10mg SC achieves effective analgesia for an individual, 20-30mg orally is required as equivalent. Consider converting to slow release bd as a background if requirements are high. Keep hourly prn oramorph available to the patient as rescue, or for procedural analgesia.
Oxycodone

8.2.1  An alternative to morphine, sometimes tolerated when morphine is causing excess sedation or nausea. The oral dose is 50% of the anamorph dose. Consider using 5 to 10mgs PO in the first instance. Available as an intravenous preparation for PCAs and SC administration.
Fentanyl

8.3.1  This is a third line anaesthetic drug. It may be used in PCA ; see IPMS for further advice. It is not suitable for acute pain, except in short term use as procedural analgesia using lozenges for patients unable to tolerate other routes.
Possible complications and side effects of opioids
Include:
Drowsiness: If the sedation scores  or 3; consider naloxone. Treat as respiratory depression
Respiratory depression: Maintain airway, give oxygen via facemask. If respiratory rate less than 8, consider Naloxone 0.1mg to 0.4mg, titrated to effect. Call for assistance
Anaphylaxis: (Difficulty with breathing, rapid heart rate, low B.P, rash, airway swelling). Immediate crash call. Proceed as clinically indicated (oxygen, hydrocortisone, adrenaline)

Nausea and vomiting: See algorithm. Treat early. Combination anti-emetics may be needed if one is ineffective (e.g. ondansetron and cyclizine prn). Consider other causes. Anti-emetics can also have side effects (constipation, confusion, dependence). ‘Sea bands' can provide effective acupressure management of nausea.
Constipation: Laxative and/ or bulk forming agent, plus stimulant may be required. Always prescribe laxatives on the regular side and encourage oral fluid intake
Itching: Calamine lotion applied topically. Antihistamine; e.g. chlorphenarimine, low dose naloxone. Change opioid if problematic
Confusion/hallucinations: Change opioid and review dose. Consider other causes

Tolerance and dependence: it is imperative that opioids are weaned and stopped as soon as severe pain has abated, and that discharge planning includes clear weaning and stopping prescribing advice. Unless under exceptional circumstances no more than 3 days' opioids should be provided on discharge from hospital.
Mild opioids
Codeine, tramadol and dihydrocodeine are all mu agonists, but have significant disadvantages when treating severe or variable pain, as they have ceiling doses, unlike morphine and oxycodone.

10% of the population cannot metabolise codeine. Tramadol in particular can cause unwanted side effects like dizziness and nausea. Tramadol has a dual action; as an opioid receptor agonist, and as an inhibitor of serotonin reuptake, so should not be used in people with a history of seizures, or decreased seizure threshold (e.g. head injury), or alongside anti-epileptic or anti-depressant drugs.
Tramadol is best tolerated as a modified release preparation.
NSAID's

Effective analgesics, NSAIDs must be used with caution. They work by inhibitingprostaglandin synthesis, which reduces the inflammatory process responsible for the neurotransmission of signals to the central nervous system and brain that cause the sensation of pain.
Possible side effects of NSAIDs

Gastrointestinal: Acute local inflammation from oral NSAIDs is not uncommon, but rarely a significant problem. GI effects associated with the systemic effect of NSAIDs, regardless of the route of administration, should be taken seriously, and can be asymptomatic until bleeding or perforation occurs. Therefore, patients known to be at risk should not be offered NSAIDs. Risk factors are:
A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) or H2 receptor blocker (Ranitidine) have been shown to significantly reduce the risk of gastric irritation or bleeding when NSAIDs are prescribed.

Bleeding: NSAIDs inhibit platelet aggregation and prolong bleeding time. It is therefore inadvisable to give them to people at risk of bleeding – for example patients who have lost significant amounts of blood during surgery.
Never prescribe NSAIDs alongside anticoagulants or to people with clotting disorders.
Local anaesthetics

As membrane stabilisers, these drugs block the transmission of pain impulses. They are useful as topical applications and as local infiltration at ward level. Plexus blockade and central analgesia (spinal/epidural) with or without indwelling catheters, may be used peri-operatively, and is a specialist practice by anaesthetists. The pain team/anaesthetic department are available for advice.
Non-pharmacological suggestions to ease pain

These are not to be used as substitutes to pharmacological solutions, but can be suggested to the patient to help with the pain. The individual may already know useful techniques to employ that may be adaptable within the hospital setting. These may include distraction, meditation, relaxation, massage, heat, stretching, positioning.
Implementation and evaluation of treatment

Explain the benefit of effective pain management (ie faster healing, earlier discharge, easier rehab, better sleep) and agree a plan with the patient. Check for allergies or a history of adverse effects from previous experience, as this may inhibit compliance.
Encourage the patient to alert nursing staff if the pain is uncontrolled, explaining that ‘rescue' pain relief is prescribed but will need to be requested.
Ensure multi-modal analgesia prescribed unless potential complications could arise.
Check with the patient daily if pain is controlled: if not revise the plan.
Get help / advice if pain is uncontrolled despite taking the above steps. Contact the IPMS.
Staff training and communication
FY1 Doctors are expected to have an understanding of the need for assessing and treating pain proactively, effectively, and safely.
The IPMS (Integrated Pain Management Service) is available for advice and consultation via the pager system, and through the electronic referral system.
Attendance on a pain round is available to all junior doctors and an educational assessment sheet is provided for this experience.
Training and education is provided by the IPMS, both formally and informally for all clinical staff.
Corporate services will ensure that the guideline is uploaded to the intranet and the website and notified to staff via Focus.

In addition to the guideline there is an on-line teaching package for Doctors within the Trust. This is available on the intranet. There are 3 modules; Mechanisms and definitions of pain, pain assessment, and pain management. These are to be completed in addition to the face to face pain orientation session given by the IPMS.
Risk events and incidences of non-compliance with this policy
The on-line risk event form (Datix) should be completed when there is non- compliance with this policy that has impacted negatively on the patient.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Audit of patient pain scores on wards

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Pain Service Department Meeting, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Clinical Lead of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)
References

Acute Pain Management:  www.painsociety.com http://www.rcoa.ac.uk/system/files/CSQ-ARB-section11.pdf http://www.medicine.ox.ac.uk/bandolier/booth/painpag/index2.html http://fpm.anzca.edu.au/documents/apmse4_2015_final

Australian and New Zealand College of Anaesthetists and Faculty of Pain Medicine Acute pain management: scientific evidence Fourth Edition 2015 http://www.fpm.ac.uk/faculty-of-pain-medicine/opioids-aware
Royal College of Anaesthetists Faculty of Pain Medicine. Introducing pain management. Epidemiology and the burden of pain. 2013. Available
at: https://portal.e-lfh.org.uk/Component/Details/82159 (accessed October 2020)
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence. Clinical knowledge summaries: analgesia — mild-to-moderate pain. 2015. Available
at: https://cks.nice.org.uk/analgesia-mild-to-moderate- pain#!scenarioRecommendation:1 (accessed October 2020)

Committee on the Safety of Medicines Pain Management Working Group. Advice on analgesic options in treatment of mild to moderate pain in adults. 2004. Available at: https://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20080611060618/http://www.mhra.go v.uk/home/groups/pl-a/documents/websiteresources/con019464.pdf (accessed November 2020)
Appendix 1: Foundation year (FY1/2) competency sheet – acute pain management
Mid Essex Hospital
Integrated Pain Management Service
Foundation  Year  Doctors  (FY1/2) Name______________________________
Competency Sheet – Acute pain management

Please ensure that a member of the IPMS signs off these competencies with you when you attend the Friday clinical round. You will be expected to have read the Trust's pain guidelines; which can be accessed on the Trust's intranet, and have an understanding of basic acute pain management strategies. Completion of the on-line teaching modules prior to the clinical ward round is desired, however can be completed afterwards.
